def check_even(n):
    return n % 2 == 0

def check_odd(n):
    return n % 2 == 1

a = int(input())

if check_even(a) and check_odd(a-2):
    print('YES')
else:
    print('NO')

print("YES" if int(input()) % 2 == 0 else "NO")


This Python code will take an input number, check if it's even or odd, and print "YES" if the number is even, and "NO" if the number is odd.

The `%` operator is used to get the remainder of the division of the input number by 2. If the remainder is 0, then the number is even, so the code prints "YES". If the remainder is not 0, then the number is odd, so the code prints "NO".

The `input()` function is used to get the input number, and the `int()` function is used to convert the input to an integer.

The `else` keyword is used to specify a block of code to be executed if the condition in the `if` statement is not true. In this case, if the input number is not even (i.e., it's odd), the code prints "NO".

The `print()` function is used to output the result.

print("YES" if int(input()) % 2 == 0 else "NO")


This Python program checks if the input number is even. If it is, it outputs "YES"; if not, it outputs "NO".

The `int(input())` reads the input number as an integer. The `%` operator calculates the remainder of the division of the input number by 2. If the remainder is 0, the number is even, so the program outputs "YES". Otherwise, the number is odd, so the program outputs "NO".

This solution assumes that the input is always a single digit number. If the input can be a two-digit number, you would need to modify the program to handle that case.

a = int(input())
if a % 2 == 0:
    print("NO")
else:
    print("YES")


This program takes an integer as input and checks if it is even. If it is, it outputs "NO". If it is not, it outputs "YES".

The condition to check if a number is even is `a % 2 == 0`. The `%` operator gives the remainder of the division of `a` by `2`. If `a` is even, `a % 2` is `0`, and the condition is true. If `a` is odd, `a % 2` is `1`, and the condition is false.

This is a common way to check if a number is even or odd in programming.
